elements.content: Five new entangled metal−organic frameworks {[Co(H2L)2(HCOO)2] (1), [Ni(H2L)2(HCOO)2] (2), [Co(HL)2]·2H2O (3), [Ni(H2L)2(SO4)]·2H2O (4), and [Ag2(L)] (5)} were synthesized by reactions of the corresponding metal salts with rigid ligand 1,4-di(1H-imidazol-4-yl)benzene (H2L). These compounds were characterized by single crystal X-ray structural determination, IR, thermogravimetric analysis, and powder X-ray diffraction. The isostructural behavior is observed between compounds 1 and 2. Both 1 and 2 are 3D frameworks with 3-fold inclined interpenetration of 2D (4,4) networks, where the formate anions generated from the hydrolysis of DMF molecules act as counteranions and terminal ligands. Complex 3 possesses a 6-fold interpenetrated 3D porous dia framework, while 4 is a 4-fold interpenetrated dia net decorated by the sulfate ions, which suppress the occurrence of high-fold interpenetration. In 5 each fully deprotonated ligand (L2−) coordinates with four Ag(I) atoms to form a 3-fold interpenetrated CdSO 4 -like framework. In addition, the stability and adsorption properties of the complexes were studied.

elements.content: Five new entangled metal−organic coordination polymers were synthesized by reactions of metal salts with rigid 1,4-di(1H-imidazol-4-yl)benzene (H2L) ligand, and their structures were determined by X-ray diffraction analyses. The adsorption property of the complex was explored.

elements.content: Metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted much attention, owing to their enormous variety of intriguing structures, interesting properties, and potential applications, such as gas storage, separation, catalysis, ion exchange, and sensing. Interpenetrated frameworks, an important and intriguing type of entangled architectures, are characterized by the presence of two or more independent networks that are inextricably entangled through the rings belonging to one framework. It is widely acknowledged that the origin of interpenetration can be ascribed to the presence of large free voids in a single framework, and interpenetration will occur to fill the void space, which benefits the thermal stability of the frameworks. In this sense, interpenetration reduces the effective void volume of porous frameworks to some extent, but it may fortify their functionalities, such as improvement of hydrogen storage capacities and selective sorption of gas molecules, based on their dynamic nature of such an interpenetrated framework. Therefore, recent reports show a boom in the exploratory synthesis using long spacer ligands to construct interpenetrated porous frameworks to establish the feasibility for selective gas sorption.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted much attention, owing to their enormous variety of intriguing structures, interesting properties, and potential applications, such as gas storage, separation, catalysis, ion exchange, and sensing. Interpenetrated frameworks, an important and intriguing type of entangled architectures, are characterized by the presence of two or more independent networks that are inextricably entangled through the rings belonging to one framework. It is widely acknowledged that the origin of interpenetration can be ascribed to the presence of large free voids in a single framework, and interpenetration will occur to fill the void space, which benefits the thermal stability of the frameworks. In this sense, interpenetration reduces the effective void volume of porous frameworks to some extent, but it may fortify their functionalities, such as improvement of hydrogen storage capacities and selective sorption of gas molecules, based on their dynamic nature of such an interpenetrated framework. Therefore, recent reports show a boom in the exploratory synthesis using long spacer ligands to construct interpenetrated porous frameworks to establish the feasibility for selective gas sorption.

elements.content: The long spacer ligands, particularly the rigid N,N′-bidentate donors, are efficient building blocks, which could favor the formation of interpenetrated motifs. During the past decade, our group has utilized a series of 1H-imidazol-1-yl-containing ligands as building blocks in the construction of MOFs. Currently, we designed and synthesized a novel 1H-imidazol-4-yl-containing ligand, 1,4-di(1H-imidazol-4-yl)benzene (H2L), as an extension of the systematic studies on 1H-imidazol-1-yl-containing ligands. Obviously, ligand H2L can act as a neutral bidentate with these two imidazole groups to ligate two metal ions in the similar way as ligand bib did (Scheme ), and their corresponding complexes should have an anionic part to balance the positive charge of the metal ions. The beauty of ligand H2L is that upon deprotonation it can also serve as an anionic tetradentate with each imidazolate anion to ligate two metal ions, thus enriching the structural topologies of the resulting complex and, more importantly, increasing the effective void space due to the absence of counteranions. Herein we report the syntheses and crystal structures of five new entangled metal complexes: [Co(H2L)2(HCOO)2] (1), [Ni(H2L)2(HCOO)2] (2), [Co(HL)2]·2H2O (3), [Ni(H2L)2(SO4)]·2H2O (4), and [Ag2(L)] (5). The stabilities and adsorption properties of the complexes were also investigated.

elements.content: All commercially available chemicals and solvents are of reagent grade and were used as received without further purification. The ligand H2L was synthesized according to the literature. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C Elemental Analyzer at the analysis center of Nanjing University. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal analyzer under nitrogen with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. FT-IR spectra were recorded in the range 400−4000 cm−1 on a Bruker Vector22 FT-IR spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. Solid state UV−visible spectra were measured on a Shimadzu UV3600 spectrophotometer. Power X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation. Water vapor (H2O) and nitrogen (N2) sorption experiments were carried out on a Belsorp-max volumetric gas sorption instrument. The sample was activated by using the “outgas” function of the surface area analyzer for 24 h at 120 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All commercially available chemicals and solvents are of reagent grade and were used as received without further purification. The ligand H2L was synthesized according to the literature. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C Elemental Analyzer at the analysis center of Nanjing University. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal analyzer under nitrogen with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. FT-IR spectra were recorded in the range 400-4000 cm-1 on a Bruker Vector22 FT-IR spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. Solid state UV-visible spectra were measured on a Shimadzu UV3600 spectrophotometer. Power X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation. Water vapor (H2O) and nitrogen (N2) sorption experiments were carried out on a Belsorp-max volumetric gas sorption instrument. The sample was activated by using the "outgas" function of the surface area analyzer for 24 h at 120 °C.

elements.content: A reaction mixture of H2L (21.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (14.6 mg, 0.05 mmol), and DMF (N,N-dimethylformamide, 2 mL) in 10 mL of H2O was sealed in a 16 mL Teflon lined stainless steel container and heated at 120 °C for 3 days. After cooling to room temperature, purple block crystals of 1 were collected by filtration and washed with water and ethanol several times, with a yield of 78%. Anal. Preparation of [Ag2(L)] (5)

A solution of H2L (21.0 mg, 0.1 mmol) in methanol (7 mL) was layered over a solution of AgNO3 (16.9 mg, 0.1 mmol) in aqueous ammonia (25%, 2 mL) and H2O (5 mL). elements.content: The crystallographic data collections for 1−4 were carried out on a Bruker Smart Apex CCD area-detector diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K using the ω-scan technique. The diffraction data were integrated by using the SAINT program, which was also used for the intensity corrections for the Lorentz and polarization effects. Semiempirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods, and all the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically on F 2 by the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-97 crystallographic software package. The hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically. The C atoms of the benzene ring on the 14-, 15-, 17-, and 18-positions in 4 are disordered into two positions with site occupancies of 0.66(2) and 0.34(2), respectively. And the two water molecules in 4 are disordered into two positions with site occupancies of 0.449(15), 0.551(15) and 0.728(13), 0.272(13), respectively. The crystallographic data for 5 was collected on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID imaging plate diffractometer at 200 K, with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71075 Å). The structure was solved by direct methods with SIR92 and expanded using Fourier techniques. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by the full matrix least-squares method on F 2. All calculations were carried out on an SGI workstation using the teXsan crystallographic software package of Molecular Structure Corporation. The details of the crystal parameters, data collection, and refinements for the complexes are summarized in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles with their estimated standard deviations are listed in Table .

Crystallography

The crystallographic data collections for 1-4 were carried out on a Bruker Smart Apex CCD area-detector diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K using the ω-scan technique. The diffraction data were integrated by using the SAINT program, which was also used for the intensity corrections for the Lorentz and polarization effects. Semiempirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods, and all the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically on F 2 by the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-97 crystallographic software package. The hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically. The C atoms of the benzene ring on the 14-, 15-, 17-, and 18-positions in 4 are disordered into two positions with site occupancies of 0.66(2) and 0.34(2), respectively. And the two water molecules in 4 are disordered into two positions with site occupancies of 0.449(15), 0.551(15) and 0.728(13), 0.272(13), respectively. The crystallographic data for 5 was collected on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID imaging plate diffractometer at 200 K, with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71075 Å). The structure was solved by direct methods with SIR92 and expanded using Fourier techniques. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by the full matrix least-squares method on F 2. All calculations were carried out on an SGI workstation using the teXsan crystallographic software package of Molecular Structure Corporation. The details of the crystal parameters, data collection, and refinements for the complexes are summarized in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles with their estimated standard deviations are listed in Table .

Compounds 1−4 were synthesized under hydrothermal/solvothermal conditions. Complexes 1 and 2 were obtained under the same reaction conditions using Co(NO3)2·6H2O and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, respectively, and they have the same structures. 1 and 2 were synthesized at 120 °C for 3 days, and such relatively harsh conditions lead to the in situ generation of formate anions from the decomposition of DMF solvent. Complex 3 was synthesized with a similar procedure as that for 1 except that the reaction temperature was lowered to 80 °C, and no formate anion was observed in 3. Interestingly, ligand H2L in 3 was found to be partially deprotonated. Although NaOH was added during the preparation of 4, the ligand was kept intact, probably due to the strong coordination ability of the sulfate anion. It has been reported that the aqueous ammonia can effectively benefit the deprotonation of imidazole in the related Ag(I), Cu(I), and Cu(II) complexes. The Ag(I) imidazolate complex 5 was successfully obtained in the NH3/H2O reaction system. Thus, the H2L ligands in 1−5 have three charge types of neutral in 1, 2, and 4, charge −1 in 3, and charge −2 in 5, as described above, which further demonstrated that factors such as the nature of the ligand, reaction medium, reaction temperature, pH value, and counterions have a great effect on the reactions of this system. The pure phase of the synthesized 1−5 was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements, as shown in Figure S2 of the ; each PXRD pattern of the as-synthesized sample is well consistent with the simulated one.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses and Thermal Stabilities of the Complexes

Compounds 1-4 were synthesized under hydrothermal/solvothermal conditions. Complexes 1 and 2 were obtained under the same reaction conditions using Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O and Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O, respectively, and they have the same structures. 1 and 2 were synthesized at 120 °C for 3 days, and such relatively harsh conditions lead to the in situ generation of formate anions from the decomposition of DMF solvent. Complex 3 was synthesized with a similar procedure as that for 1 except that the reaction temperature was lowered to 80 °C, and no formate anion was observed in 3. Interestingly, ligand H2L in 3 was found to be partially deprotonated. Although NaOH was added during the preparation of 4, the ligand was kept intact, probably due to the strong coordination ability of the sulfate anion. It has been reported that the aqueous ammonia can effectively benefit the deprotonation of imidazole in the related Ag(I), Cu(I), and Cu(II) complexes. The Ag(I) imidazolate complex 5 was successfully obtained in the NH3/H2O reaction system. Thus, the H2L ligands in 1-5 have three charge types of neutral in 1, 2, and 4, charge -1 in 3, and charge -2 in 5, as described above, which further demonstrated that factors such as the nature of the ligand, reaction medium, reaction temperature, pH value, and counterions have a great effect on the reactions of this system. The pure phase of the synthesized 1-5 was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements, as shown in Figure S2 of the ; each PXRD pattern of the as-synthesized sample is well consistent with the simulated one.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed to verify the thermal stability of these five compounds, and the results are shown in Figure S3 of the . No obvious weight losses were found for complexes 1 and 2 before the decomposition of the framework occurred at about 230 and 210 °C, respectively. Complex 3 shows a weight loss of 7.09% in the temperature range 140−220 °C, corresponding to the release of lattice water molecules (calcd 7.01%), and the decomposition of the residue occurred at 250 °C. For 4, a weight loss of 5.70% was observed in the temperature range 90−130 °C, which corresponds to the loss of the free water molecules (calcd 5.89%); further weight loss was observed at about 380 °C. No obvious weight loss was found for 5 before the decomposition of the framework occurred at about 355 °C.

elements.content: Complexes 1 and 2 crystallize in the same monoclinic P21/c space group with similar cell parameters (Table ), and the results of X-ray crystallographic analysis indicate that they are isomorphous and isostructural. Thus, as a typical example, only the structure of 1 is described here in detail. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains one Co(II) ion, two halves of H2L ligand, and one formate anion. In 1 the H2L ligand acts as a neutral building block and the formate anions terminally coordinate to the Co(II) ions. As illustrated in Figure a, the Co1 is located at an inversion center with an octahedral coordination environment surrounded by four N atoms from four different H2L ligands forming the basal plane and two O donors from two different formate anions occupying the apical positions. In 1 two H2L ligands and two Co(II) ions form a macrocycle through the coordination bonds, where the lateral Co···Co distances are 13.99 and 13.97 Å, and the diagonal Co···Co distances are 20.75 and 18.75 Å, respectively. Thus, the shape of this macrocycle is nearly a rhombus. In 1, each H2L links two Co(II) ions to form a two-dimensional (2D) (4,4) net along the bc plane (Figure b). The 3D entanglement of complex 1 is established by the 3-fold inclined interpenetration of 2D nets (Figure c).

elements.content: Complex 3 was solvothermally synthesized at lower temperature (80 °C) to avoid the decomposition of DMF solvent. Complex 3 crystallizes in tetragonal P42/n space group, and the asymmetric unit has a quarter of Co(II) cation, a half of partially deprotonated (HL)− ligand, and a half of water molecule. Figure a shows the coordination environment of the Co(II) atom with the atom numbering scheme. Co1 atom is in a distorted tetrahedral coordination environment with four N atoms from four distinct (HL)− ligands with Co−N bond distances of 1.968(2) Å and N−Co−N bond angles in the range 107.16(7)−114.19(14)° (Table ). The connections of the tetrahedral node of Co(II) and linear linker of the (HL)− ligand make 3 a 3D dia net with large rectangle channels (23.68 Å × 20.24 Å) (Figure b). The large vacancy within the adamantanoid cage (Figure c) and relatively slim ligand facilitate the high-fold interpenetration. In order to minimize the big hollow cavities in 3 and stabilize the overall network, the large cavities within the structure are completely filled via mutual interpenetration of the independent frameworks, leading to the formation of a 6-fold interpenetrating 3D architecture (Figure d). Despite the 6-fold interpenetration, the total void value of the channel is estimated (calculated by PLATON) to be 245.1 Å3, approximately 19.0% of the total crystal volume of 1288.2 Å3 filled by water molecules (Figure e).

elements.content: In spite of NaOH being added to the reaction system, the H2L remains as a natural ligand and the positive charges of the metal ions are balanced by sulfate ions. Complex 4 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P21/n (Table ). As shown in Figure a, the central Ni(II) atom is six-coordinated with distorted octahedral coordination geometry by four N atoms (N1, N5, N3B, N7A) from four different H2L ligands and two O atoms (O3, O4) from one chelating sulfate anion, with Ni1−N bond distances ranging from 2.032(3) to 2.077(3) Å and Ni1−O ones of 2.177(3) and 2.222(3) Å, respectively (Table ). In 4 each ligand links two metal ions and each metal ion in turn bridges four ligands. Such a connection pattern leads to the formation of a 3D dia net with large channels (34.49 Å × 15.46 Å) (Figure b and c). In 4, the adamantanoid cage also shows a large cavity (Figure d), which is interpenetrated by three other independent frameworks (Figure e).

elements.content: Complex 5 was obtained in a NH3/H2O solution system by the layering method. Crystallographic analysis showed that 5 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c. The asymmetric unit of 5 contains two halves of Ag(I) and a half of deprotonated L2− ligand (Figure a). Both Ag1 and Ag2 adopt a linear coordination geometry with two N atoms from two different L2− ligands [Ag1−N = 2.097(2), Ag2−N = 2.087(2) Å, N11−Ag1−N11A = 172.18(12), and N12−Ag2−N12B = 180.0°] (Table ). The coordination environment around Ag(I) ion in 5 is compatible with that of the reported linear-coordinated Ag(I) imidazolates. As shown in Figure b, the L2− ligands are connected by Ag2 ions to form two type 1D chains, which are further linked together by Ag1 ions to generate a 3D structure. In 5, each L2− ligand coordinates with four Ag(I) atoms, and it can be regarded as a 4-connected node. Ag1 or Ag2 ion bridges two ligands together, and it can be considered as a 2-connected node. As a result the 3D framework, complex 5 is a severely distorted CdSO 4 -like net. When it is viewed along the c direction, the structure is seen to contain 13.8 Å × 13.8 Å channels. However, these channels are occupied by two other interpenetrating independent frameworks (Figure c), and the interpenetrated nets are stabilized by weak Ag···Ag interactions with the Ag−Ag distance of 3.37 Å.

elements.content: In compounds 1−4, each metal ion is coordinated by four ligands. In complex 1 or 2, these four metal−N bonds around one metal center are located essentially in one plane, and these four ligands coplanarly extend to four directions due to the rigidity of the ligands. So in 1 or 2 a 2D (4, 4) net is to be expected. In 3 and 4 the ligands around each metal center are directed by the metal ion in a tetrahedral arrangement, which leads to the formation of a 3D dia net. In 1−5, varying levels of interpenetration were observed due to the presence of the large cavities with different shape and size, which are generated by the relatively long ligand. Complexes 1 and 2 display a rare 3-fold inclined interpenetrated (4,4) net. Complex 3 is a neutral compound, since the ligand is partially deprotonated to balance the positive charge of metal ion, and it possesses a 6-fold interpenetrated 3D dia framework. It is interesting to note that compound 4 is a 4-fold interpenetrated dia net. The backbone of 4 is decorated by the bulky sulfate ions, which reduces the effective void volume and may suppress the occurrence of high-fold interpenetration. In complex 5, each ligand is coordinated to four metal ions, acting as a 4-connected node, to generate a 3-fold interpenetrated CdSO 4 -like net. It is noteworthy that the 3-fold interpenetrated CdSO 4 net is not common while there are 2-fold interpenetrated CdSO 4 net structures reported.
elements.clean_text:
Comparison of the Structures

In compounds 1-4, each metal ion is coordinated by four ligands. In complex 1 or 2, these four metal-N bonds around one metal center are located essentially in one plane, and these four ligands coplanarly extend to four directions due to the rigidity of the ligands. So in 1 or 2 a 2D (4, 4) net is to be expected. In 3 and 4 the ligands around each metal center are directed by the metal ion in a tetrahedral arrangement, which leads to the formation of a 3D dia net. In 1-5, varying levels of interpenetration were observed due to the presence of the large cavities with different shape and size, which are generated by the relatively long ligand. Complexes 1 and 2 display a rare 3-fold inclined interpenetrated (4,4) net. Complex 3 is a neutral compound, since the ligand is partially deprotonated to balance the positive charge of metal ion, and it possesses a 6-fold interpenetrated 3D dia framework. It is interesting to note that compound 4 is a 4-fold interpenetrated dia net. The backbone of 4 is decorated by the bulky sulfate ions, which reduces the effective void volume and may suppress the occurrence of high-fold interpenetration. In complex 5, each ligand is coordinated to four metal ions, acting as a 4-connected node, to generate a 3-fold interpenetrated CdSO  4 -like net. It is noteworthy that the 3-fold interpenetrated CdSO  4  net is not common while there are 2-fold interpenetrated CdSO  4  net structures reported.

elements.content: In order to explore the gas sorption property of the porous material 3, TGA and PXRD measurements were carried out to ascertain the thermal stability of the porous framework (Figure S3 of the and Figure a). The samples 3a for gas sorption experiments were prepared by heating 3 at 120 °C under vacuum for 24 h to remove all guest H2O molecules. The TGA (Figure S3 of the ) curve of compound 3a indicates that it has no guest H2O molecules and its framework decomposes at 250 °C, which is also confirmed by the PXRD patterns at different temperatures (Figure a). The room temperature PXRD pattern of as-synthesized sample 3 is consistent with the simulated one. However, the PXRD pattern of desolvated host framework 3a is different from that of 3, which indicates the flexibility of the overall framework due to the loosely packed 6-fold interpenetrated framework. The framework transformation may occur during the desolvation process, since the lose of solvent molecules in a porous complex results in shrinkage or expansion of the channels. When the dehydrated solid 3a is exposed to water vapor, the PXRD pattern of the rehydrated solid matches quite well with that of 3 (Figure b), indicating a reversible dehydration−rehydration process.
elements.clean_text:
Dynamic Nature of the Framework and Gas Sorption Property

In order to explore the gas sorption property of the porous material 3, TGA and PXRD measurements were carried out to ascertain the thermal stability of the porous framework (Figure S3 of the  and Figure a). The samples 3a for gas sorption experiments were prepared by heating 3 at 120 °C under vacuum for 24 h to remove all guest H2O molecules. The TGA (Figure S3 of the ) curve of compound 3a indicates that it has no guest H2O molecules and its framework decomposes at 250 °C, which is also confirmed by the PXRD patterns at different temperatures (Figure a). The room temperature PXRD pattern of as-synthesized sample 3 is consistent with the simulated one. However, the PXRD pattern of desolvated host framework 3a is different from that of 3, which indicates the flexibility of the overall framework due to the loosely packed 6-fold interpenetrated framework. The framework transformation may occur during the desolvation process, since the lose of solvent molecules in a porous complex results in shrinkage or expansion of the channels. When the dehydrated solid 3a is exposed to water vapor, the PXRD pattern of the rehydrated solid matches quite well with that of 3 (Figure b), indicating a reversible dehydration-rehydration process.

elements.content: A further study was subsequently undertaken to investigate the gas adsorption property of the desolvated sample 3a. As shown in Figure a, compound 3a exhibits low N2 uptake at 77 K. The adsorption and desorption hysteresis loop was observed extending to the lowest attainable pressure, which is characteristic of type-H3. The H2O vapor adsorption isotherm of 3a is illustrated in Figure b. The isotherms show large hysteresis and stepwise profiles, which is similar to that of the doubly interpenetrated 3D porous SNU-9. The adsorption amount, 6.99 wt % of H2O at 298 K and 1 atm (86.70 cm3/g at STP), corresponds to 1.85 H2O molecule per formula unit, which is pretty close the maximum amount of two H2O molecules within one cell unit, as indicated by crystallographic analysis. Its affinity for H2O is ascribed to the hydrophilic channels, which is constructed from the electron-rich conjugate π system of deprotonated Im− and is decorated by uncoordinated N atoms. When adsorbate H2O molecules access the contractive narrow pores, the diffusion barrier requires activation energy. The abrupt adsorption at 0.12P/P 0 represents the “break-though” point, where the sufficient pressure exists to overcome the diffusion barrier and allows the saturation of the pores, and these interpenetrated frameworks can alter their pore sizes through host−guest interaction to induce the gate-opening. In most cases, the sorption isotherms show hysteretic behaviors due to framework rearrangements during adsorption−desorption processes, which can be further confirmed by the inconsistent PXRD patterns between desolvated sample and rehydrated sample (Figure b).

elements.content: Five new entangled MOFs with different connection patterns and varying levels of interpenetration were obtained on the basis of the 1H-imidazol-4-yl-containing ligand H2L, which serves as a ditopic neutral ligand or as a tetradentate imidazolate anion to meet the different coordination requirements of metal centers depending on reaction conditions. Thus, we believe that the deprotonated ligand L2− is efficient for the construction of hybrid frameworks, which may lead to a new family of coordination framework materials. Complexes 1−5 have entangled structures with different topologies: 1 and 2 possess 2D layer motifs which aggregate into a 2D + 2D → 3D mutually inclined interpenetrated system; 3 and 4 are 6-fold and 4-fold interpenetrated dia 3D nets, respectively; 5 is a 3-fold interpenetrated CdSO 4 -type 3D net. Interestingly, 3 showed the dynamic nature of a flexible interpenetrated framework by virtue of the adsorption for H2O vapor.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Five new entangled MOFs with different connection patterns and varying levels of interpenetration were obtained on the basis of the 1H-imidazol-4-yl-containing ligand H2L, which serves as a ditopic neutral ligand or as a tetradentate imidazolate anion to meet the different coordination requirements of metal centers depending on reaction conditions. Thus, we believe that the deprotonated ligand L2- is efficient for the construction of hybrid frameworks, which may lead to a new family of coordination framework materials. Complexes 1-5 have entangled structures with different topologies: 1 and 2 possess 2D layer motifs which aggregate into a 2D + 2D → 3D mutually inclined interpenetrated system; 3 and 4 are 6-fold and 4-fold interpenetrated dia 3D nets, respectively; 5 is a 3-fold interpenetrated CdSO  4 -type 3D net. Interestingly, 3 showed the dynamic nature of a flexible interpenetrated framework by virtue of the adsorption for H2O vapor.

A reaction mixture of H2L (21.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (14.6 mg, 0.05 mmol), and DMF (N,N-dimethylformamide, 2 mL) in 10 mL of H2O was sealed in a 16 mL Teflon lined stainless steel container and heated at 120 °C for 3 days. After cooling to room temperature, purple block crystals of 1 were collected by filtration and washed with water and ethanol several times, with a yield of 78%. Anal. Calcd for C26H22N8O4Co: C, 54.79; H, 3.86; N, 19.67. Found: C, 54.56; H, 3.98; N, 19.46. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3117(w), 3003(w), 1604 (m), 1577(vs), 1510(m), 1359(s), 1267(w), 1141(m), 1074(w), 945(m), 834(m), 652(m).

Preparation of [Ni(H<sub>2</sub>L)<sub>2</sub>(HCOO)<sub>2</sub>] (<bold>2</bold>)

cln_elements.content:
Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed to verify the thermal stability of these five compounds, and the results are shown in Figure S3 of the . No obvious weight losses were found for complexes 1 and 2 before the decomposition of the framework occurred at about 230 and 210 °C, respectively. Complex 3 shows a weight loss of 7.09% in the temperature range 140−220 °C, corresponding to the release of lattice water molecules (calcd 7.01%), and the decomposition of the residue occurred at 250 °C. For 4, a weight loss of 5.70% was observed in the temperature range 90−130 °C, which corresponds to the loss of the free water molecules (calcd 5.89%); further weight loss was observed at about 380 °C. No obvious weight loss was found for 5 before the decomposition of the framework occurred at about 355 °C.

A further study was subsequently undertaken to investigate the gas adsorption property of the desolvated sample 3a. As shown in Figure a, compound 3a exhibits low N2 uptake at 77 K. The adsorption and desorption hysteresis loop was observed extending to the lowest attainable pressure, which is characteristic of type-H3. The H2O vapor adsorption isotherm of 3a is illustrated in Figure b. The isotherms show large hysteresis and stepwise profiles, which is similar to that of the doubly interpenetrated 3D porous SNU-9. The adsorption amount, 6.99 wt % of H2O at 298 K and 1 atm (86.70 cm3/g at STP), corresponds to 1.85 H2O molecule per formula unit, which is pretty close the maximum amount of two H2O molecules within one cell unit, as indicated by crystallographic analysis. Its affinity for H2O is ascribed to the hydrophilic channels, which is constructed from the electron-rich conjugate π system of deprotonated Im− and is decorated by uncoordinated N atoms. When adsorbate H2O molecules access the contractive narrow pores, the diffusion barrier requires activation energy. The abrupt adsorption at 0.12P/P 0 represents the “break-though” point, where the sufficient pressure exists to overcome the diffusion barrier and allows the saturation of the pores, and these interpenetrated frameworks can alter their pore sizes through host−guest interaction to induce the gate-opening. In most cases, the sorption isotherms show hysteretic behaviors due to framework rearrangements during adsorption−desorption processes, which can be further confirmed by the inconsistent PXRD patterns between desolvated sample and rehydrated sample (Figure b).
